blocks.text: Essentials
Source: ATA 2015 Thyroid Nodule Guidelines, Section A10 (Recommendations for diagnostic FNA based on sonographic pattern).

items: US survey of thyroid and cervical lymph nodes is required for all suspected thyroid nodules.
FNA is the procedure of choice when clinically indicated; thresholds are driven by sonographic risk pattern and size.
Patterns: high, intermediate, low, very low suspicion, and benign; each carries a malignancy risk band and FNA size cutoff.
Suspicious cervical lymph nodes should be biopsied and trigger FNA of likely primary even if subcentimeter.
Elastography may aid risk assessment when available, but evidence is variable; it should not replace gray-scale US.

Diagnostic FNA indications by sonographic pattern and size (Fig. 2, Table 6).
Sonographic Pattern Definitions
Use in tandem with size thresholds above.

items: High suspicion: solid hypoechoic (or hypoechoic solid part of cystic) with any of irregular margins (infiltrative, microlobulated, spiculated), microcalcifications, taller-than-wide shape, disrupted rim calcification with extrusive soft tissue, or extrathyroidal extension.
Intermediate suspicion: hypoechoic solid with smooth margins, no microcalcifications, no extrathyroidal extension, not taller-than-wide.
Low suspicion: isoechoic/hyperechoic solid, or partially cystic with eccentric solid areas, without microcalcifications, irregular margin, extrathyroidal extension, or taller-than-wide shape.
Very low suspicion: spongiform or partially cystic without any high/intermediate/low suspicious features.

Risk Pattern Details

High suspicion nodules >=1 cm should undergo FNA; micropapillary cancers <1 cm are often indolent but may grow or produce nodal metastases, especially in patients <40 years. Intermediate suspicion nodules >=1 cm merit FNA. Low suspicion nodules (iso/hyperechoic or partially cystic with smooth eccentric solid areas) merit FNA at >=1.5 cm. Very low suspicion (spongiform/partially cystic without worrisome features) carry <3% risk; FNA may be deferred until >=2 cm and observation is reasonable. Pure cysts are benign; no diagnostic FNA.

Sonographically suspicious cervical lymph nodes (microcalcifications, cystic change, peripheral vascularity, hyperechogenicity, round shape) warrant FNA and Tg washout as indicated; subcentimeter primary nodules should be sampled if nodes are suspicious.

Elastography Note

Ultrasound elastography (USE) can provide tissue stiffness estimates but performance is variable and operator dependent. It applies best to solid nodules without overlapping structures and is not a substitute for gray-scale US. Limited availability and lower positive predictive value mean USE should not change the recommendation to perform standard gray-scale sonography; consider in selected cases as adjunctive risk assessment.
